verses.text: He called the Twelve together and gave them power and authority over all demons and to heal diseases.
verses.comment: Jesus grants both authority and power to the apostles, not only over physical ailments but also spiritual forces. This anticipates a continuing ministry through them. Spiritual authority here is foundational for the apostles’ special role in leading others (see also Acts 1:8).

verses.text: And he sent them out to preach the kingdom of God and to heal the sick.
verses.comment: Their mission is both preaching and healing—word and deed together. The message is inseparable from its tangible effects. Jesus’ followers continue this holistic mission.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Take nothing for the journey—no staff, nor bag, nor bread, nor money; and do not have two tunics each.'
verses.comment: Jesus calls for radical dependence on God’s providence and hospitality among the faithful. It hints at a trusting dependence practiced by later leaders.

verses.text: Whatever house you enter, stay there and leave from there.
verses.comment: Apostles are told to accept hospitality rather than search for better accommodations, reflecting humility and simplicity fitting for gospel workers.

verses.text: Wherever they do not receive you, when you leave that town, shake the dust from your feet as a testimony against them.
verses.comment: This gesture was a symbol of separation and warning. Refusing the apostolic message is serious, for it is God sent. Compare with Old Testament prophetic warnings (see Ezekiel 3:16-21).

verses.text: They went out and traveled from village to village, preaching the gospel and healing everywhere.
verses.comment: Their ministry echoes Jesus’ own—preaching and healing as signs of the kingdom among the people.

verses.text: Now Herod the tetrarch heard of all that was happening, and he was greatly perplexed because some were saying that John had been raised from the dead.
verses.comment: Rumors about Jesus’ identity show the extraordinary nature of his ministry. Herod is confronted with the supernatural, revealing a troubled conscience.

verses.text: Others said that Elijah had appeared, and others that one of the ancient prophets had risen.
verses.comment: The expectation of Elijah or a prophet fulfilled messianic hopes (Malachi 4:5; Deut. 18:18). Jesus surpasses these figures, pointing to his unique role.

verses.text: But Herod said, 'John I beheaded. But who is this about whom I hear such things?' And he sought to see him.
verses.comment: Herod’s questions underline confusion about Jesus’ identity and mission. The search for Jesus signifies the attraction and disturbance He caused even among rulers.

verses.text: When the apostles returned, they told him all they had done. And he took them and withdrew privately to a town called Bethsaida.
verses.comment: Jesus values rest and time for reflection with his closest followers, showing the importance of spiritual retreats and guidance.

verses.text: But when the crowds found out, they followed him. He welcomed them, spoke to them about the kingdom of God, and healed those who needed healing.
verses.comment: Jesus exhibits compassion, continuing his ministry despite interruptions. The kingdom of God proclamation is central, matched to acts of healing.

verses.text: Now the day began to draw to a close. The Twelve came and said to him, 'Send the crowd away to the surrounding villages and countryside, to find lodging and get food, for we are here in a desolate place.'
verses.comment: The disciples’ pragmatic concern shows their limits, setting the stage for Jesus’ miraculous work. The wilderness evokes Old Testament echoes of God providing manna (Exodus 16).

verses.text: But he said to them, 'You give them something to eat.' They said, 'We have no more than five loaves and two fish, unless we go and buy food for all these people.'
verses.comment: Jesus invites the disciples to cooperate with His work, anticipating their future role in spiritual feeding. The loaves and fish foreshadow deeper sacramental realities (see John 6:9-13; 1 Cor. 10:16-17).

verses.text: For there were about five thousand men. He said to his disciples, 'Have them sit down in groups of about fifty each.'
verses.comment: The orderly grouping recalls Israel encamped in the wilderness, with echoes of leadership structures established for worship and service.

verses.text: They did so, and made them all sit down.
verses.comment: Obedience to Jesus’ instructions prepares the way for his miraculous provision.

verses.text: Taking the five loaves and the two fish, he looked up to heaven, blessed and broke them, and gave them to the disciples to set before the crowd.
verses.comment: The actions—taking, blessing, breaking, and giving—prefigure the institution of the Eucharist (see Luke 22:19). The parallels point toward Jesus’ desire to nourish his people through his own provision.

verses.text: They ate and were all satisfied. What was left over was picked up—twelve baskets of broken pieces.
verses.comment: Twelve baskets underline the fullness of God's provision for spiritual Israel. The miracle symbolizes the abundance found in Christ's spiritual food for believers.

verses.text: Now it happened as he was praying alone, his disciples were with him. He asked them, 'Who do the crowds say that I am?'
verses.comment: Jesus often prays before significant events, modeling prayer for the Church. His question leads into a major revelation of His identity.

verses.text: They answered, 'John the Baptist. Others say Elijah, and others that one of the prophets of old has risen.'
verses.comment: Echoes common messianic hopes. In Luke, the disciples voice several opinions, setting up Jesus’ deeper question.

verses.text: Then he said to them, 'But who do you say that I am?' Peter answered, 'The Christ of God.'
verses.comment: Peter confesses Jesus as the Messiah (Christ means Anointed One), identifying him as the fulfillment of Old Testament hopes (see Psalm 2:2). This is a pivotal moment of revealed truth to the Church’s first leader.

verses.text: He strictly charged and commanded them to tell this to no one,
verses.comment: Jesus often withholds full public revelation of his identity until the proper time, emphasizing God’s plan unfolds gradually.

verses.text: saying, 'The Son of Man must suffer many things, and be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and on the third day be raised.'
verses.comment: Jesus foretells His passion and resurrection, fulfilling Isaiah’s suffering servant prophecy and Psalm 16. He refers to Himself as 'Son of Man' in line with Daniel 7:13–14, a title with divine overtones.

verses.text: Then he said to all, 'If anyone would come after me, let him deny himself, take up his cross daily, and follow me.'
verses.comment: Christian discipleship is ongoing self-denial and carrying one’s cross with Jesus—showing salvation involves cooperation with grace, not mere belief.

verses.text: For whoever would save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for my sake will save it.
verses.comment: A paradoxical teaching: true life is found in self-sacrificial following of Jesus. The cross-shaped way is the means of salvation.

verses.text: For what does it profit a man if he gains the whole world and loses or forfeits himself?
verses.comment: Earthly gain is nothing compared to the value of the soul; the teaching warns against materialism, urging eternal priorities.

verses.text: For whoever is ashamed of me and my words, of him will the Son of Man be ashamed when he comes in his glory, and the glory of the Father and of the holy angels.
verses.comment: Jesus speaks with the authority of the judge at the final judgment, implying his divinity (Daniel 7). The Christian must unapologetically confess Jesus.

verses.text: But I tell you truly, there are some standing here who will not taste death until they see the kingdom of God.
verses.comment: Some interpreters see fulfillment at the Transfiguration, others at Pentecost, or the spread of the Church. 'Kingdom of God' signals the continuing presence and expansion of Christ's reign.

verses.text: About eight days after these sayings, he took with him Peter, John, and James, and went up on the mountain to pray.
verses.comment: The mountain is a place of divine encounter—the context is prayer, reiterating the importance of communion with God before moments of revelation.

verses.text: As he was praying, the appearance of his face became different, and his clothing became dazzling white.
verses.comment: This manifestation reveals Jesus’ divine glory. The change echoes Moses’ face shining after meeting God but surpasses it, confirming Jesus is more than a prophet.

verses.text: Behold, two men were talking with him—Moses and Elijah—
verses.comment: Moses represents the Law, Elijah the Prophets. Their presence testifies that all revelation points to and is fulfilled in Jesus.

verses.text: who appeared in glory and spoke of his departure, which he was about to accomplish at Jerusalem.
verses.comment: 'His departure' (literally 'exodus') points to his redemptive death and resurrection—the new Passover, leading God’s people to salvation.

verses.text: Peter and those with him were heavy with sleep, but when they were fully awake, they saw his glory and the two men standing with him.
verses.comment: The disciples struggle with spiritual alertness, yet are privileged to witness the divine glory. Seeing Jesus’ glory is a foretaste of the new covenant.

verses.text: As the men were parting from him, Peter said to Jesus, 'Master, it is good that we are here. Let us make three tents, one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah,' not knowing what he said.
verses.comment: Peter’s response, desiring to prolong the moment, reflects both awe and confusion. Tents likely refer to the Feast of Tabernacles, recalling God's presence.

verses.text: As he was saying this, a cloud came and overshadowed them; and they were afraid as they entered the cloud.
verses.comment: The cloud is a sign of God’s presence, as in the Exodus. God the Father manifests Himself, confirming Jesus’ unique status.

verses.text: A voice came out of the cloud, saying, 'This is my Son, my Chosen One; listen to him.'
verses.comment: The Father identifies Jesus as divine Son and chosen servant from prophecy (see Psa. 2:7; Isa. 42:1), urging obedience to the one supreme teacher. This is a high Christological moment pointing to Jesus' divinity.

verses.text: When the voice had spoken, Jesus was found alone. They kept silent and in those days told no one anything of what they had seen.
verses.comment: The uniqueness of Christ is underlined—Moses and Elijah vanish, leaving only Jesus. The disciples’ silence may signal awe, or Jesus’ instruction to await the right time for revelation.

verses.text: The next day, when they had come down from the mountain, a great crowd met him.
verses.comment: Jesus descends from divine revelation to continue his ministry on earth—linking heaven and earth in his mission.

verses.text: Behold, a man from the crowd cried out, 'Teacher, I beg you, look on my son, for he is my only child.'
verses.comment: The plea for a son echoes the prayers of parents throughout the Bible, underlining the compassion Jesus brings as God's Son.

verses.text: Behold, a spirit seizes him, and he suddenly cries out; it convulses him and he foams at the mouth, and it bruises him and will hardly leave him.
verses.comment: Describes an epileptic-like demonic affliction, showing the tragic consequences of evil and pointing to Jesus’ unique authority to heal and redeem.

verses.text: I begged your disciples to cast it out, but they could not.
verses.comment: The disciples' inability highlights the necessity of deeper faith and reliance on Jesus’ own authority.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'O faithless and twisted generation, how long am I to be with you and bear with you? Bring your son here.'
verses.comment: Jesus laments the spiritual blindness present, showing the persistent struggle with faith. The phrase echoes language of Old Testament prophets.

verses.text: While he was coming, the demon threw him down and convulsed him. But Jesus rebuked the unclean spirit, healed the child, and gave him back to his father.
verses.comment: Jesus’ authority extends over evil spirits and physical illness—a sign that the kingdom of God has arrived in power.

verses.text: All were astonished at the majesty of God. But while they were all marveling at everything he was doing, he said to his disciples,
verses.comment: The miracles point to God’s majesty displayed in Jesus. Yet he immediately turns attention to his coming passion—earthly glory will not be his way.

verses.text: 'Let these words sink into your ears: The Son of Man is about to be delivered into the hands of men.'
verses.comment: Once again, Jesus predicts his betrayal and suffering, referencing Old Testament prophecy. True kingship will come through self-giving and suffering.

verses.text: But they did not understand this saying; it was concealed from them, so that they might not perceive it. And they were afraid to ask him about this saying.
verses.comment: The disciples’ incomprehension is due in part to their expectations, but also by divine design—they must experience the resurrection to understand the cross.

verses.text: An argument arose among them as to which of them was the greatest.
verses.comment: Strife over greatness repeatedly surfaces among the apostles, reminding believers that leadership in God’s kingdom is defined differently.

verses.text: But Jesus, knowing the reasoning of their hearts, took a child and set him by his side,
verses.comment: Jesus discerns hearts—not only actions. Elevating a child models humility and the attitude all leaders are encouraged to have.

verses.text: and said to them, 'Whoever receives this child in my name receives me, and whoever receives me receives him who sent me. For he who is least among you all is the one who is great.'
verses.comment: True greatness is found in humble service, in imitation of Christ’s own humility. Reception of the lowly is equated with receiving Jesus himself.

verses.text: John answered, 'Master, we saw someone casting out demons in your name, and we tried to stop him because he does not follow with us.'
verses.comment: John’s concern reveals a tendency toward exclusivism. The Spirit’s gifts sometimes operate in unexpected places, but true unity is important.

verses.text: But Jesus said to him, 'Do not stop him, for the one who is not against you is for you.'
verses.comment: A generous spirit is called for; the Church embraces those who act with Christ’s authority, so long as they are not opposing his mission.

verses.text: When the days drew near for him to be taken up, he set his face to go to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Jesus resolutely focuses on his passion and ascension. This is a turning point—the central mission is now in sharp view. His determination fulfills prophetic resolve.

verses.text: He sent messengers ahead of him, and they went and entered a village of the Samaritans to prepare for him.
verses.comment: Jesus reaches out even to Samaritans—traditional outsiders. The inclusive scope of His mission prefigures the universal call to all nations.

verses.text: But the people did not receive him, because his face was set toward Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Samaritan rejection stemmed from religious disagreements regarding Jerusalem. Jesus’ journey foreshadows the mixed reception of the gospel.

verses.text: When his disciples James and John saw it, they said, 'Lord, do you want us to command fire to come down from heaven and consume them?'
verses.comment: James and John echo Elijah's calling down fire. Jesus brings not judgment, but mercy, marking a new way for his followers.

verses.text: But he turned and rebuked them.
verses.comment: Jesus rebukes revenge. His followers are called to love enemies, consistent with His earlier teaching (Matthew 5:44).

verses.text: And they went on to another village.
verses.comment: The mission moves forward in peace, even in the face of rejection. The Church’s advance does not depend on compulsion or violence.

verses.text: As they were going along the road, someone said to him, 'I will follow you wherever you go.'
verses.comment: Jesus attracts would-be disciples who must understand discipleship’s cost.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Foxes have holes and birds of the air have nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to lay his head.'
verses.comment: Discipleship may require letting go of earthly comforts and security for God’s kingdom, as modeled by Jesus.

verses.text: To another he said, 'Follow me.' But he said, 'Lord, let me first go and bury my father.'
verses.comment: The claim legitimizes family duty, but Jesus’ summons to discipleship outranks all other loyalties.

verses.text: But Jesus said to him, 'Let the dead bury their own dead. But you go and proclaim the kingdom of God.'
verses.comment: Radical commitment to the gospel takes precedence, even over traditional religious or familial obligations.

verses.text: Another also said, 'I will follow you, Lord, but let me first say farewell to those at my home.'
verses.comment: Elisha was permitted a farewell (1 Kings 19:20); Jesus demands a higher loyalty—illustrating the surpassing call of the new covenant.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'No one who puts his hand to the plow and looks back is fit for the kingdom of God.'
verses.comment: Total commitment is required for discipleship. Like Elisha breaking his plow or Lot’s wife not looking back, Christians are called to undivided focus and loyalty to God’s kingdom.
